comments.author: Marina@Picnic at Marina
comments.content: Oh yes, I am all for number two: there are so many other choices on the table, I never had a problem to feed myself vegetarian! :)

comments.author: Emma
comments.content: Interesting topic!  This year, I'm actually attending an omnivorous event and bringing a veg main (I'm leaning toward butternut squash lasagna), and then hosting a veggie event the following day, so I guess I'm pretty firmly in camp 1.  For me, it has to do with the special-ness  of the day-- it really feels like an EVENT if there's an exciting main course.  Add to that my brother's general cluelessness (he's likely to forget and add bacon to several things, for instance, and I can guarantee that there will be a Jello salad) and I will be better off making sure I have my own goodies.  After all, just because I'm a vegetarian doesn't mean I don't want to overeat on Thanksgiving!

comments.author: angie
comments.content: My sister is in Camp #2, but when I cook for her, I like to make a veg entree.  The problem is, she hates mushrooms!  Any help for me?

comments.author: Maureen | Orgasmic Chef
comments.content: I'm with you on #2.  It's always the "sides" that get all the attention anyway.

comments.author: Patrick B.
comments.content: Most turkey is overrated and I'm all about #2. All your suggestions are great. I'm looking through trying to decide which I might bring to our Thanksgiving.

comments.author: angie
comments.content: YES!  The squash sounds perfect!!  Thanks!

comments.author: emmycooks
comments.content: I'm usually with you on the no-vegetarian-main thing, except that your suggestions here look so good!  I could happily eat my way through that buffet of sides, though, and want for nothing.  I might not even be able to wait a week to try that brown butter cornbread!

comments.author: angela@spinachtiger
comments.content: When I was a vegetarian, I could easily be happy finding food at the Thanksgiving table without making a big deal out of it. It's all about those sides right?

comments.author: Jenny
comments.content: Those polenta cakes look amazing!  And caramelized apples... drool.  Personally, I dread the "I made something special for you" line. But that's just because omnivores generally have NO clue what vegetarians like to eat!  That and the whole "chicken and fish are vegetarian" misconception. Oh, and the "I'll just add a little chicken broth to her food because without meat she'll DIE!" and, yeah.  I had Taco Bell on the way, I'm good.  But really, what I wouldn't give to sit down at a table with all of the above spread out before me.  Mmmmm...

comments.author: Katie (The Muffin Myth)
comments.content: I'm with you in camp 2. Those polenta cakes look amazing, though, I'll definitely have to try them out. Thanks for sharing this list of amazing looking recipes.

comments.author: Betty Ann @Mango_Queen
comments.content: What a great recipe round up for the holidays! This all looks so delish and yet so healthy! Thanks for sharing this with us, Michael ! Happy Thanksgiving! I am grateful to have met you last May at EWR 12 and thankful for all the wonderful recipes you share.

comments.author: Bernadette Phipps-Lincke
comments.content: Some great recipes here. Thank you!

comments.author: marie lipari
comments.content:
A new song I liked about Thanksgiving turkey by a college student who is vegan:
www.youtube.com/watch?v=pvIFDhZ3Ejw

Who are the turkeys in our lives? This Thanksgiving, maybe we can do something for them.
